009package imagingbook.common.geometry.fitting.circle.algebraic;
010
011
012import static imagingbook.common.math.Arithmetic.sqr;
013
014import org.apache.commons.math3.linear.MatrixUtils;
015import org.apache.commons.math3.linear.RealMatrix;
016import org.apache.commons.math3.linear.RealVector;
017
018import imagingbook.common.geometry.basic.Pnt2d;
019import imagingbook.common.geometry.basic.PntUtils;
020import imagingbook.common.math.PrintPrecision;
021import imagingbook.common.math.eigen.EigenDecompositionJama;
022import imagingbook.common.util.SortMap;
023
024/**
025 * <p>
026 * This is an implementation of the "hyperaccurate" algebraic circle fit proposed
027 * by Al-Sharadqah and Chernov in [1], also described in [2] (Sec. 7.5, Eq. 744).
028 * This method combines the Pratt and Taubin fits to eliminate the essential bias.
029 * This version is "optimized for speed, not for stability"
030 * (see https://people.cas.uab.edu/~mosya/cl/Hyper.m), also referred to 
031 * as "simple" version. 
032 * Fits to exactly 3 (non-collinear) points are handled properly.
033 * Data centering is used to improve numerical stability (alternatively, a reference
034 * point can be specified).
035 * Note that this algorithm may fail on certain critical point constellations, see 
036 * {@link CircleFitHyperStable} for a superior implementation.
037 * </p>
038 * <p>
039 * [1] A. Al-Sharadqah and N. Chernov. "Error analysis for circle fitting algorithms".
040 * <em>Electronic Journal of Statistics</em>, 3:886â€“911 (2009).
041 * <br>
042 * [2] N. Chernov. "Circular and Linear Regression: Fitting Circles and
043 * Lines by Least Squares". Monographs on Statistics and Applied Probability.
044 * Taylor &amp; Francis (2011).
045 * </p>
046 * 
047 * @author WB
048 *
049 */
050public class CircleFitHyperSimple implements CircleFitAlgebraic {
051
052        private final double[] q;       // q = (A,B,C,D) circle parameters
053
054        /**
055         * Constructor.
056         * The centroid of the sample points is used as the reference point.
057         * 
058         * @param points sample points
059         */
060        public CircleFitHyperSimple(Pnt2d[] points) {
061                this(points, null);
062        }
063        
064        /**
065         * Constructor.
066         * The centroid of the sample points is used as the reference point for data
067         * centering if {@code null} is passed for {@code xref}.
068         * 
069         * @param points sample points
070         * @param xref reference point or {@code null}
071         */
072        public CircleFitHyperSimple(Pnt2d[] points, Pnt2d xref) {
073                this.q = fit(points, xref);
074        }
075
076        @Override
077        public double[] getParameters() {
078                return this.q;
079        }
080
081        // -------------------------------------------------------------------------
082
083        private double[] fit(Pnt2d[] pts, Pnt2d xref) {
084                PrintPrecision.set(3);
085
086                final int n = pts.length;
087                if (n < 3) {
088                        throw new IllegalArgumentException("at least 3 points are required");
089                }
090                
091                if (xref == null) {
092                        xref = PntUtils.centroid(pts);
093                }
094                final double xr = xref.getX();
095                final double yr = xref.getY();
096
097                double[][] Xa = new double[n][];
098                double xs = 0;  // sum of x_i
099                double ys = 0;  // sum of y_i
100                double zs = 0;  // sum of z_i
101                for (int i = 0; i < n; i++) {
102                        double x = pts[i].getX() - xr;
103                        double y = pts[i].getY() - yr;
104                        double z = sqr(x) + sqr(y);
105                        Xa[i] = new double[] {z, x, y, 1};
106                        xs = xs + x;
107                        ys = ys + y;
108                        zs = zs + z;
109                }
110
111                double xm = xs / n;     // mean of x_i
112                double ym = ys / n;     // mean of y_i
113                double zm = zs / n;     // mean of z_i
114
115                RealMatrix X = MatrixUtils.createRealMatrix(Xa);
116                RealMatrix D = (X.transpose()).multiply(X);
117
118                // data-dependent constraint matrix:
119//              RealMatrix C = MatrixUtils.createRealMatrix(new double[][]
120//                              {{ 8 * zm, 4 * xm, 4 * ym, 2 },
121//                               { 4 * xm, 1,      0,      0 },
122//                               { 4 * ym, 0,      1,      0 },
123//                               { 2,      0,      0,      0 }});
124//              RealMatrix Ci = MatrixUtils.inverse(C);
125                
126                // define the inverse constraint matrix directly:
127                RealMatrix Ci = MatrixUtils.createRealMatrix(new double[][]
128                                {{ 0,   0, 0, 0.5 }, 
129                                 { 0,   1, 0, -2 * xm }, 
130                                 { 0,   0, 1, -2 * ym },
131                                 { 0.5, -2 * xm, -2 * ym, 4 * (sqr(xm) + sqr(ym)) - 2 * zm }});
132
133                RealMatrix CiD = Ci.multiply(D);
134                EigenDecompositionJama ed = new EigenDecompositionJama(CiD);
135                double[] evals = ed.getRealEigenvalues();
136                
137                int l = new SortMap(evals).getIndex(1); // index of the 2nd-smallest eigenvalue (1st is negative)
138                RealVector qq = ed.getEigenvector(l);
139                
140                RealMatrix M = CircleFitAlgebraic.getDecenteringMatrix(xr, yr);
141                return M.operate(qq).toArray(); // q = (A, B, C, D)             
142        }
143
144}
